lexUnit.name: laud.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: praise highly, especially in a public context.

sentence.text: The Francophone press has lauded the acquisition as a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to ` safeguard the patrimony " .
Ministry officials highlighted the plan 's architectural merits and lauded it as a demonstration of their firm and timely commitment to the Prado 's needs .

A former chief of the US Drug Enforcement Administration , an organisation regarded as a firm enemy of Noriega , swore to tell the whole truth and proceeded to laud Noriega for his ` long-standing support " and ` personal commitment " to the drug wars .

He smiled ruefully as he read the commentaries which a week before had been excoriating him and for the most part were now , in their fickle and inconstant fashion , lauding him for his statesmanlike and responsible action in allowing the Government to make a fresh start -- ` although he must still resolve many outstanding personal and family issues to the public 's satisfaction " , thundered The Times .
Contemporaneous critics lauded this new cinema in which people were no longer made up to look like ` artificial dolls " ( Willett 1978 , p. 146 ) .
She can be exhilaratingly dismissive , as when she lauds Hanif Kureishi for not writing like Penelope Fitzgerald .
It has received international recognition and a long and impressive list of visitors -- including the Prime Minister -- have lauded its achievements .
For those who want a little more than Dulux Silk Emulsion , may we recommend ‘ Colefax & Fowler , the Best In English Interior Decoration ’ , a publication lauding the USM-listed interior decorator .
Conversely , he lauds any ideas , however shaky , that will promote controversy as ` interesting and entertaining " ( the inevitable spandrels ) and ` really very exciting " .
John Hutchinson lauds such programming , admitting that , ` It helps define nationalist ideas , so we 're not subsumed into the British Isles .
Wilson 's work has been lauded by the centre-left in the United States and is an important reminder that not all Americans are Reaganites .
Their arrest was lauded as a triumph of international co-operation among the police forces of Canada , Britain , New Zealand and Thailand .
Once Britain was lauded for its education system .
They are lauded for stimulating the Japanese economy through a recent ¥13 trillion ( $116 billion ) supplementary budget and for ‘ rescuing ’ the stockmarket .
While she is lauded in London intellectual circles , she is less well-known to the general public .
The Constitution has been lauded as " a living organism in a condition of perpetual growth . "
The greater suitability of children for the new tasks was lauded in terms of their " quickness " and their " nimble " fingers .
A band is discovered , lauded , and then examined with an intensity that would frighten vampires .
In his speech Assad lauded the achievements of the Progressive National Front ( the ruling Ba'ath-dominated coalition ) , but refused to rule out the future launch of new political parties .
Without irony , the brochure goes on to laud the district 's ` picturesque villages " .
Unfortunately , Mr Clarke only delivered another speech lauding the Government 's plans for the NHS .
Conservatives have always lauded the ` voluntarist " principle in welfare , and encouraged it from platforms .

However , while he 's lauded in the West for his achievements , at home the award means much less ; perestroika has lost much of its appeal and simply means yet more empty shelves in the shops and more despondency about the economy .

Netanyahu stated that Li had assured him that China has cancelled out on proposed plans to build an atomic reactor for Iran ... One would hope that the specific pledge that I received in Beijing reflects a general Chinese decision to prevent the arming of Iran . [ World Journal ( in Chinese ) , 25 August 1997 ; Israeli PM Lauds China For Cancelling Iran Reactor , Reuter , 26 August 1997 ; Netanyahu Says Received China Assurances On Iran , Reuter , 24 August 1997 . ]
